title: The Zero-Sum Battlefield: A Guide to the Broken Economics of Healthcare
summary: Why are insurers and hospitals at war? The conflict between Blue Cross Blue Shield of Vermont and UVMMC is a symptom of a broken system. This educational guide explains the concepts of 'Fee-For-Service,' 'Value-Based Care,' and 'Global Budgets' to show why the current model is failing patients and what a solution actually looks like.

children.text: The current war between Blue Cross Blue Shield of Vermont (BCBSVT) and the University of Vermont Medical Center (UVMMC) is not just a local squabble. It is a textbook example of what happens when a healthcare system gets stuck halfway between two economic models. To understand why your MRI costs $6,500, we first need to understand the three core concepts that govern how money moves in healthcare: The Widget Model, The All-Payer Dream, and The Global Budget Solution.

Most healthcare in America, including much of Vermont's commercial market, runs on 'Fee-For-Service' (FFS). Think of this like a grocery store. Every item has a price tag. If you buy an apple, you pay $1. If you buy a steak, you pay $20. The store makes more money the more items you put in your cart.

In healthcare, the 'items' are tests, scans, and surgeries. The hospital (the store) wants to sell you more MRIs (steaks) because they are profitable. The insurer (the shopper) wants to buy fewer items to save money. This creates a natural conflict: The hospital wants high volume and high prices; the insurer wants low volume and low prices.

code.Explanation: UVMMC charges more because they use 'Steak' profits to pay for the Emergency Room (which loses money).

children.text: Vermont tried to fix this with the 'All-Payer Model.' The idea was simple: All insurance companies (Medicare, Medicaid, and Blue Cross) should play by the same rules. Instead of fighting 3 different wars, the hospital would have one unified agreement.

However, this model is currently failing in the commercial sector because it hasn't changed the *payment mechanism* for individual services. We have an 'All-Payer' agreement in name, but we are still fighting 'Fee-For-Service' battles in practice. The hospital still needs to sell expensive MRIs to survive, and the insurer still needs to stop them.
Concept 3: The Solution (Value-Based Care & Global Budgets)

This is the 'Subscription Model' (Global Budget). Imagine if instead of paying for every apple and steak, the insurer paid the hospital a flat fee of $1,000 per month to keep you fed and healthy. This is called a Global Budget.
Under this model, the economic incentives flip upside down:

code.Fee-For-Service Model: Hospital WANTS to do it. It earns them $6,520.
code.Global Budget Model: Hospital sees it as a COST. They lose money doing it.

code.Fee-For-Service Model: Bad for business. Empty beds = $0 revenue.
code.Global Budget Model: Great for business. Full payment received, $0 costs incurred.

children.text: If Vermont moved to a true Global Budget (like Maryland has done), the war over MRI prices would end instantly. Why? Because UVMMC would no longer 'sell' MRIs. They would receive a guaranteed annual budget to care for the population. In that world, UVMMC would happily send you to the cheaper independent center for your scan, because it saves *them* money against their own budget. The incentives of the insurer and the hospital would finally align: Quality up, costs down.

body.caption: Educational: Value-Based Care vs. Fee-For-Service explained simply.
